Rachel, 32 years old, lives together with her husband. They both work hard to get ahead in life. She works from home. She has a store in which she sells perishable and essential goods. She has a few loyal customers.

Because she has lacked the money, Rachel has not been able to restock her business. Restocking is very important to improving her profits and stability, because it will attract more clients.

Rachel is requesting a loan from Yehu with which she will be able to buy the products she needs including soap, detergent, beverages and basic grains. This will guarantee the continuation of her business.

loans.use: to buy products for her general store including soap, detergent, beverages and basic grains.

loans.name: Phelomena

texts.en:
Phelomena is 53 years old, in a common-law relationship with her husband and has five grown children. She and her family reside in a rural community in the town of Mwambalazi.

Phelomena has been selling food products and groceries for five years. She sells basic grains, soft drinks, hygiene and cleaning products, flour, and snack foods. 

She is requesting a loan in the amount of 30,000 KES so that she can invest in the purchase of flour, dairy products, sugar, condiments, soft drinks, and detergents. She says that if her business is well-stocked, then she will gain more customers and increase her earnings. Her goal is to expand her shop and offer more products to her customers.

loans.use: to purchase flour, dairy products, sugar, condiments, soft drinks and detergents.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 40 years old, married and has three children, ages 1 to 7. He sells goats and currently employs one person to help him. He has 15 years experience in this work. 

Emmanuel has requested a loan from Kiva lenders, via Vision Finance Company, to buy more goats for resale. He plans to use any profits generated from this loan to satisfy his family's basic needs and to reinvest in his business.

loans.use: To purchase more goats for resale.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is 31 years old, married and has three children, who are dependents. She lives with her husband and children in one of the rural communities that comprise the rural district of Msambweni, located in Kenya's Coast Province.
Her business is selling groceries, beverages and snacks, and basic grains. She has done this for over two years approximately, in a store she has set up in her house. She is open every day and she currently has a well-established clientele. She's very well-known in the area. She uses the profits she gets from her business to help her husband support their family's finances.
Janet is requesting a loan from Yehu for the fourth time. It is for 20,000 KES, which she plans to invest in the purchase of merchandise such as rice, sugar and oil to stock up her grocery store.
She gives thanks in advance to Kiva lenders for supporting her at this time.

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of merchandise such as rice, sugar and oil.

loans.name: Alima

texts.en:
Alima is 49 years old, in a common-law relationship, and has six children. She lives with her family in the town of Mwambalazi.
Five years ago, she started her business of selling coconuts. Alima came up with the idea to establish this business because she wanted to help her partner with the family expenses.

At the moment, she wants to restock with more products that are in great demand. For this reason, she is requesting a loan in the amount of 20,000 KES. She hopes to invest her earnings in the growth of her business and in the expenses for her family.

loans.use: to buy more coconuts to sell.

loans.name: Tambi Emmanuel

texts.fr:
Mr T. EMMANNUEL est célibataire avec 03 enfants. Le plus âgé a 17ans et le moins âgé a 10ans. Ils vont à l’école  et  il a 03 personnes  à sa charge.

Il est étudiant en classe de Master I professionnelle à l’ESTPO (Ecole Supérieure des Travaux Public de Ouagadougou) depuis 04ans. Parce que L’ESTPO est une école de référence en matière de formation en génie civil dans notre pays.

Mr veut financer ses études supérieures.

Il fait des stages pratiques  pendant les vacances pour acquérir une expérience professionnelle. Il compte après ses études, travailler d’abord, ensuite créer son propre entreprise et éduquer ses enfants.
texts.en:
Emmanuel is single and he has three children.  His oldest child is 17 years old, his youngest is 10.  All three go to school. Emmanuel has three people in his care.

For the past four years Emmanuel has been enrolled at the ESTPO or "Ecole Supérieure des Travaux Publics de Ouagadougou" (Ouagadougou Graduate School for Public Works), where he is a graduate student.  The ESTPO is a top civil engineering school in our country.

He wants to finance his graduate studies.

During school breaks he does internships in order to acquire professional experience.  After graduation he would like to find employment and then create his own company.  He also wants to take care of his children's education.

loans.use: to finance his graduate studies.

loans.name: Wend Pagnangde Ghislain

texts.fr:
Mr  WENDPAGNANDE GHISLAIN est célibataire sans enfant.

Il  est étudiant en classe de Master I  professionnelle à l’ESTPO (Ecole Supérieure des Travaux Public de Ouagadougou) depuis  2ans. Parce que L’ESTPO est une école de référence en matière de formation en génie civil dans notre pays.

Mr  veut financer ses études supérieures.

Il fait des stages pratiques  pendant les vacances pour acquérir une expérience professionnelle et réussir brillement à l’école.  Après les  études, il compte  avoir du boulot et avoir des enfants.
texts.en:
Mr. WEND PAGNANDE GHISLAIN is single and has no children.

For two years, he has been a first-cycle Master’s Degree student in an applied science program at ESTPO (Ouagadougou Graduate School for Public Works). ESTPO is one of the schools of reference for public works in our country.

He wants to finance his graduate studies.

During the holidays, he did practical internships to gain professional experience and to succeed brilliantly at school. After his studies, he is planning on finding work and on founding a family.

loans.use: to finance his graduate studies.

loans.name: N. Philippe

texts.fr:
Mr  NONGWENDE PHILIPPE est célibataire sans enfant.
Il est étudiant en classe de Master I professionnelle à l’ESTPO (Ecole Supérieure des Travaux Public de Ouagadougou) depuis  3ans. Parce que L’ESTPO est une école de référence en matière de formation en génie civil dans notre pays.
Mr veut financer ses études supérieures.
Il fait des stages pratiques  pendant les vacances pour acquérir une expérience professionnelle. Il envisage après les études, oeuvrer pour la nation en participant à la réalisation des infrastructures à leurs gestions et  leurs entretiens.
texts.en:
Nongwende Philippe is single and has no children. 

He has been a student of the professional Master I at Ecole Supérieure des Travaux Public de Ouagadougou (Ouagadougou Graduate School for Public Works) for 3 years. Because this is a reputed school in the country for training in civil engineering, he would like [to continue] to finance his higher education. 

Nongwende Philippe does internships during the holidays to acquire work experience. After his studies, he hopes to work for the country to develop infrastructure, as well as [be involved in] their management and maintenance.

loans.use: to finance his higher education

loans.name: Z . Hyacinte B

texts.fr:
Mr  Z HYANCINTE B est célibataire sans enfant.
Il est étudiant en classe de Master I professionnelle à l’ESTPO (Ecole Supérieure des Travaux Public de Ouagadougou) depuis  2011.
Mr veut financer ses études supérieures.
Au terme de ses études, son ambition  serait de décrocher un travail pour participer au développement de son payer. Fonder un foyer et surtout intervenir dans l’humanitaire
texts.en:
Mr. Z. Hyacinte B. is single without children.
He has been a graduate student at the “Ecole Supérieure des Travaux Public de Ouagadougou" (Ouagadougou Graduate School for Public Works) since 2011. He would like to finance his graduate studies. After finishing his studies, his goal is to obtain a job  contributing to the to the development of his country,  start a family, and certainly be be active in humanitarian work.

loans.use: to pay for his graduate studies.

loans.name: Jean Marie

texts.fr:
Mr JEAN MARIE est célibataire avec 02 enfants. Le plus âgé a 08ans et le moins âgé a 10mois. Un va à l’école  et  il a 08 personnes  à sa charge.

Il est étudiant en classe de Master II professionnelle à l’ESTPO (Ecole Supérieure des Travaux Public de Ouagadougou) depuis 04ans.

Mr veut financer ses études supérieures.

Il compte après ses études créer une entreprise afin de subvenir à  ses besoins et celui de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Jean Marie is single and has two children - the youngest of whom is 10 months old and the oldest of whom is 8 years old. One goes to school, and he has 8 dependents total.

For the past four years, he has been enrolled at the "Ecole Supérieure des Travaux Publics de Ouagadougou" (Ouagadougou Graduate School for Public Works) where he is completing the second year of coursework for his Masters degree. He would like to finance his education.

After his studies, he would like to start a business in order to meet his needs as well as the needs of his family.

loans.use: to finance his education.

loans.name: Bozorgul

texts.ru: Бозоргулу 35 лет. Она замужем и на воспитании имеет 4  детей.  Бозоргул всегда старается обеспечить своих детей со всеми не обходимыми средствами, так как ее муж тракторист и у него маленький доход. Более 4 года она занимается купле продажей женской одежды. Она имеет торговую точку на местном рыке. Ее товар привлекает много клиентов, так как Бозоргул всегда обновляет ассортимент своего товара. Она должна купить товар для нового сезона, но не имеет достаточного средства для этого. Она запрашивает займ на сумму 1500 сомони  для покупки товара для нового сезона. Она ждет вашу доброту и обещает погашать займ своевременно.
texts.en: Bozorgul is 35 years old. She is married and is raising four children. Bozorgul always tries to provide her children with all the necessary means as her husband is a tractor driver and has a small income. She has been in the business of buying and selling women's clothing for over four years. She has a vendor location on the local market. Her merchandise attracts a lot of customers because Bozorgul always renews the variety of her inventory. She needs to buy new inventory of goods for the upcoming season, but does not have enough means to do so. She is asking for a loan in the amount of 1,500 somoni to buy merchandise for new season. She awaits your kindness and promises to pay off the loan on time.

loans.use: to buy new variety of clothes for new season.

loans.name: Gbehigbenan Group

texts.fr: Le groupe « GBEHIGBENAN» est composé de deux personnes qui sont des amies. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Nicole est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Nicole est âgée de 35 ans et vit au Bénin. Nicole est mariée à un transitaire du nom de Sébastien. Le couple a trois enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés, et tous à leur charge. Nicole vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Nicole supporte ensemble avec son mari les diverses charges familiales. Pour y parvenir, Nicole vend des produits vivriers dans une ville du Bénin. Nicole achète ses produits dans un marché du Bénin. Nicole désire satisfaire un plus grand nombre de clients par ses produits, mais Nicole ne dispose pas suffisamment de moyens financiers pouvant lui permettre de rehausser le niveau de son activité. C’est pour ce faire que Nicole sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé, ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe « GBEHIGBENAN». Le crédit reçu précédemment a été bien remboursé.
texts.en: The Gbehigbenan group is made up of two people who are friends. The representative of the group, whose name is Nicole, is the one with her hand raised in the photo. Nicole is 35 years old and lives in Benin. She is married to a freight broker called Sébastien. The couple has three children to support, some of whom are at school. Nicole lives with her children and husband. She and her husband cover the various household expenses between them. In order to do this, Nicole sells food products in a town in Benin. She buys her products in a Benin market. She wants her products to provide satisfaction to a greater number of customers, but does not have sufficient financial means to increase her business volume. It is for this reason that she, together with the other member of the Gbehigbenan group, is requesting a second loan from Alidé. The previous loan was repaid in full.

loans.use: to buy food products.

loans.name: Patrician's Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are staff members in one of the leading communications companies in Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to borrow the sum of 7,600,000 Leones in order to meet their immediate financial challenges. At the end of each month, they will repay the loan using their monthly salaries. 

Patricia is the leader of this group. Patricia is 48 years of age. A native of Kenema city, she is divorced and has three children – one in college and two who are not of school-going age. Patricia has had 16 years of work experience. She has requested this loan in order to pay college fees for her child.

loans.use: to pay college fees for her child.

loans.name: Abdulai

texts.en:
In the photo is Abdulai. He is a small-scale businessman based in Kenema, a city in Eastern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan this entrepreneur is accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, Abdulai will be able to expand his businesses, make more profit and consequently improve his standard of living. 

Abdulai was born in Tongo, a town about 15 miles from Kenema city. Abdulai is single with one child who is attending primary school. He has been a businessman for six years now. He sells mobile phones and mobile phone accessories. With the help of this loan, he is going to buy mobile phones and mobile phone accessories to add to his current ones.

loans.use: to buy mobile phones and mobile phone accessories to add to his current ones.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is 47 years old, married and has four children in school. He runs a butcher shop to earn a living. He has been in the business for 12 years and employs one person. He also does farming for more income generation. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has experienced a lot of growth in his business. He thanks Faulu Kenya for training him on business management skills. He has also gained from the financial support from Faulu Kenya.

Stephen desires to practice large-scale farming in the future. He has requested a loan of 36,053.10 KES to buy a water tank. He will use the water tank for water storage on his farm.

loans.use: To buy a water tank.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
This is Rose, 41, a resident of Caloocan, Philippines. She is married to Romeo, a construction foreman and is a mother to her children. Together with her husband, she manages her household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Rose operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families only eat home-cooked meals during evenings where all of the family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to use cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands costs less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 24,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings and frozen food products. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Rose hopes that her business will expand soon and dreams of giving her children a good and quality education. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Deonila

texts.en:
This is Deonila, She previously accessed an 30,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, house hold and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 32,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Deonila hopes to be able to expand soon and dreams that her children will be successful in life She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Jinnah E.'s Group

texts.en:
Jinnah is the featured leader of this group of school teachers. He was born in Gbeika village, in Eastern Sierra Leone 50 years ago. He is married to a nurse and the couple has four children who are attending primary and secondary schools. Jinnah has served in the teaching profession for 33 years now. Jinnah will use his share of the loan to pay school fees for his children. 

SMT/Kiva lenders loans designed specifically for teachers are very helpful as they enable them to buy or invest in items that their mere salaries cannot let them do. But with the help of this loan, some of them will be able to invest in business, pay school fees for their children, buy household furniture or house-building materials, etc. and at the end of each month, they repay the loan, using their monthly salaries. It is their school’s bursar who is directly responsible for doing the deductions and making the repayments on their behalf.

loans.use: to pay school fees for his children.

loans.name: Ansumana Samuka's Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are teachers in one of the primary schools in Kenema, a city in Eastern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to borrower the sum of 8,000,000 Leones in order to meet their immediate financial challenges. At the end of each month, they will repay the loan using their monthly salaries. Their school’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayments and making the payments on their behalf.

Reynolds is the leader of this group. Reynolds is 59 years of age. Born in a place called Sami Felluma, in Eastern Sierra Leone, Reynolds is married to a businesswoman and the couple has seven children – three in primary school, three in secondary school and one in college. Reynolds has had 38 years of experience in the teaching profession. 

He has requested this loan in order to buy house-building materials like iron, corrugated zinc, cement, rods, nails, etc. to construct a family dwelling house.

loans.use: to buy house-building materials like iron, corrugated zinc, cement, rods and nails to construct a family dwelling house.

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
Miriam is a 20-year-old married woman from Antequera, Bohol. She has no children yet. She is engaged in making native products like baskets made of nito (palm). She has been in the business for one year. 

She is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase materials for additional start-up of her basket-weaving like nito (palm) and wicker (a hard woven fiber formed into a rigid material, usually used for baskets or furniture. Wicker is often made of material of plant origin, but plastic fibers are also used.) 

Miriam would like to expand her business by investing into other business ventures so she can make a better living.

loans.use: to buy nito (palm) and wicker.

loans.name: Martha Lorena

texts.es:
La señora Martha Lorena tiene un negocio de venta de calzado ubicado en uno de los mercados de la ciudad de León, lo inició de forma ambulante con ventas de ropa, actualmente tiene su puesto fijo con venta de calzado de toda índole donde ha logrado obtener mayor clientela, sale de su casa a las 6:00 am abriendo su negocio a la 6:30 y finalizando a las 5:00 pm  con este mismo horario de lunes a sábado, realiza este trabajo desde hace ocho años para el sustento de su hogar.

Sus compras las realiza al por mayor a comerciantes de la ciudad de Masaya. Es madre soltera de cinco hijos los cuales todos son mayores de edad y ninguno está a su cargo.

Martha Lorena solicita este  crédito a CEPRODEL  para compra de sandalias y zapatos de diferentes estilos para  aprovechar la demanda por  aproximarse la navidad, La señora Martha sueña con que su negocio siga creciendo.
texts.en:
Martha Lorena has a business selling footwear. Her business is located in one of the markets in the city of León. She started as a street trader selling clothes. Now she has her own stall selling all types of footwear and she has increased her number of customers. She leaves her house at 6:00am, opening her business at 6:30 and finishing up at 5:00pm. This is her work schedule from Monday to Saturday. She has been doing this work for eight years in order to sustain her family. 

She buys stock wholesale from traders in the city of Masaya. She is a single mother of five children, all of whom are grown up. None of her children are dependent on her. 

Martha Lorena is requesting this loan from CEPRODEL to buy sandals and shoes of different styles. She plans to make the most of the increasing demand coming up to Christmas. Martha hopes that her business will continue to grow.

loans.use: to buy sandals and shoes of different styles

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for maintenance of her machines.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more products from Avon to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Saturnina

texts.es:
De 50 años de edad, Saturnina tiene por pareja a Pedro con quien tiene 6 hijos casi en su totalidad mayores e independientes. Cuenta gracias al apoyo de toda su familia con su propia vivienda hecha con material noble. Hallándose en una buena oportunidad  de iniciarse en el rubro comercial, logró desde hace 8 años inagurar una tienda de abarrotes en el único ambiente amplio y acogedor de su vivienda. A medida que iba desempeñándose como tal decidió complementar su negocio con la venta de chicharrones al paso por ser uno de los productos mas consumidos por los pobladores. Considera  su negocio muy rentable ya que posee actualmente una gran cantidad de amigos y vecinos quienes son como sus fieles compradores. Dado el buen momento que lleva desea realizar la compra de mercadería para su tienda ya que ha visto por conveniente seguir incrementando de a pocos el tamaño de su negocio con el afán de a futuro convertirlo en un gran negocio completo y abastecido.
Uno de sus objetivos en adelante es el de lograr darle el acabado respectivo a su local comercial así como la ampliación del mismo con andamios y vitrinas grandes. Este viene a ser su crédito número 16 , a pesar de tener ciertas dificultades siempre fue puntual con el pago de su préstamo, le agrada el hecho de que su banco comunal sea una grupo numeroso , ya que el trabajo colectivo es una trabajo muy reconfortante para ella. Con los 1,000 nuevos soles  complementará su capital para la compra de mercadería para su negocio dentro del cual se encuentran los productos de primera necesidad como arroz , azúcar, conservar , entre otros.
texts.en:
Saturnina, 50, has six children together with Pedro, her partner. Most of them are independent adults now. Thanks to her family’s support, she owns a house made with solid materials.

Eight years ago, an opportunity arose to start a business. She opened a grocery store in the only spacious and inviting room in her house. With time, she decided to start selling chicharrón [fried, crunchy meat] on the go as a complement, since it is one of the products that locals consume the most. She considers her business to be a profitable one, because many of her friends and neighbors are loyal customers. Now that the business is experiencing a good period, she wants to buy supplies for her store, as she considers that expanding her business step by step is convenient so that in the future it can become a larger, complete and well-stocked business. One of her goals for the future is to be able to improve her store’s appearance and to add shelves and big showcases.

This will be her sixteenth credit. In the past, even if she faced some difficulties, she was able to pay back on time. She likes the fact that the communal bank is composed of numerous members, because collective work is comforting for her. With the 1000 soles [PEN], she will have enough capital to buy merchandise for her store. She will buy essential supplies such as rice, sugar and canned food.

loans.use: to buy essential supplies, such as rice, sugar and canned food.

loans.name: Rosa Argentina

texts.es:
La señora ROSA ARGENTINA  es madre  soltera de cinco  hijos  y se dedica a la venta de atol y pan, desde hace once años con la que ha desarrollado a sus hijos.

Rosa inicia a preparar su riquísimo  atol de  9:00  a 10:00 am posteriormente se traslada a venderlo a uno de los mercado de la ciudad de León Nicaragua  y finaliza a las 3:00 pm,  de 4:00 a 6:00 pm se dedica  a la venta pan de forma ambulante en las calle de dicha Ciudad.

Una de las necesidades que atraviesa  son  los gastos de graduación y estudio universitario de su hija, debido a esto visitó a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con un crédito y así  poder asegurarle  el futuro profesional de su hija.

Rosa Argentina  sueña con la preparación profesional de sus Hijos y obtener su propia vivienda ya que habita donde su Mamá.
texts.en:
ROSA ARGENTINA  is a single mother of 5 children and sells bread and atol (a traditional corn starch based drink). She has done this for 11 years and with it has raises her children. 

Rosa starts to make her delicious atol at 9:00 a.m.  At 10:00 am she takes it to sell at one of the markets in the city of León Nicaragua and finishes at 3:00 p.m. From 4:00 to 6:00 p.m. she sells bread as a street vendor in the streets of the city. 

One of the things she needs is to pay for her daughter's graduation  and college education costs. That is why she visited Ceprodel to get a loan and thus ensure her daughter's professional future. 

Rosa Argentina dreams of all of her children having professional careers and of owning her own home, since she lives with her mother.

loans.use: to pay for graduation costs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Doraliza

texts.en:
This is Doraliza. She previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities of fish and vegetables to expand her product inventory. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, house hold and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan for her to loan to pay for fish, meat and vegetables supplies she needed in her business. The more fish, meat and vegetables displayed at her stall the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Doraliza dreams of having more business and hopes to give her family a good life through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for more varieties of fish needed in her business.

loans.name: Consuelo Del Socorro

texts.es:
La Joven Consuelo del Socorro,  trabaja  en un consultorio médico en la Ciudad de León Nicaragua  desempeñándose en el área atención al cliente, realiza esta labor para ayudar a su esposo a los gastos del hogar, es madre de tres hijos  

Inicia sus labores 2:00 pm   finalizando  a las 7:00 pm  con este mismo horario de lunes a  sábado,   por la mañana se dedica a brindar  la atención a  sus queridos hijos.

Consuelo  solicita este crédito a Ceprodel  para ser   utilizado en los gastos de Graduación y título de su hija mayor, sus sueños son la preparación de sus hijos y  remodelar su humilde vivienda.
texts.en:
Consuelo del Socorro is a young woman who works in a mecial office in the city of León Nicaragua. She works in customer service and does this work to help her husband with the household expenses. She is the mother of three children.

She starts work around 2:00 p.m. and ends at  7:00 p.m. and has the same schedule Monday through Saturday. In the morning she gives her attention to her beloved children. 

Consuelo is asking for this loan from Ceprodel so she can use it to pay for expenses of graduation and getting her degree for her oldest daughter. Her dreams are to raise her children and remodel her humble home.

loans.use: to pay for graduation and degree expenses.

loans.name: Erika De Los Ángeles

texts.es:
La Joven Erika de los Ángeles, trabaja en un centro hospitalario de la Ciudad de León Nicaragua  desempeñándose como enfermera  desde hace  2 años, es madre de dos hijos de edades 12 y 8 años.

La Joven Erika  sale se sus casa a las 6:30 am y llega  a sus centro de labores  a las  7:00 am finalizando a las 3:00 pm  con este mismo horario de lunes a viernes.

Erika  es el primer crédito que solicita  a Ceprodel para cubrir gastos de graduación de uno de sus pequeños hijo y cancelación de aranceles del año escolar, ya que sus sueños son la preparación de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Erika de los Ángeles works in a hospital center in the city of León Nicaragua. She has worked as a nurse for 2 years and is the mother of two children, ages 12 and 8. 

Erika leaves her home at 6:30 a.m. and arrives at work at 7:00 a.m. She finishes at 3:00 p.m. and has this same schedule Monday though Friday.

This is the first loan that Erika has taken out with Ceprodel to cover graduation expenses for one of her children and to pay for school fees for the school year. Her dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: to pay for education expenses

loans.name: Leyerlita

texts.en:
This is Leyerlita, 41, a resident of Caloocan, Philippines. She is married to Pedrito, a worker abroad, and is a mother to her children. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Leyerlita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Leyerlita hopes to give her children a good and quality education and dreams to have a good life through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making snacks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making snacks

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
This is Conchita, She previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase merchandise items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, house hold and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 13,000 PHP loan for her to buy more merchandise items and products to increase her product inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result for better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Conchita hopes to have a good life by the grace of God. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stocks of merchandise needed in her business.

loans.name: Dania Del Carmen

texts.es:
Santa Rosa del Peñón se Llama el municipio donde habita Dania del Carmen una preciosa ciudad dedicada en diferentes actividades comerciales.

Dania necesita un financiamiento de Kiva y Ceprodel para la compra de una refrigeradora, dicho préstamo será de mucho beneficio debido a que podrá guardar sus alimentos y vivir en una mejor condición saludable con su familia. 

Es madre soltera con dos hijos bajo su cargo donde trabaja como maestra de educación primaria, con lo poco que ella gana a duras penas mantiene a su familia en su alimentación, pero debido a la necesidad que ella presenta en su hogar solicita este tipo de crédito. 

De momento solo cuenta con su buena salud, su capacidad de trabajo, su pequeña vivienda que la ha ido construyendo con muchas dificultades que ha presentado en el transcurso de su vida.
texts.en:
Dania del Carmen lives in the municipality of Santa Rosa del Peñón, a beautiful city home to a number of business activities.
Dania needs a loan from Kiva and Ceprodel to buy a refrigerator. This purchase will be very beneficial to her, since she will be able to store her food and live in healthier living conditions with her family.
She is the single mother of two children who are dependent on her. She works as a primary school teacher, and with the little that she earns, she barely supports her family with food. Due to the household need, she is requesting this type of loan.
Currently, she only has her good health, her ability to work and her small home that she has been constructing little by little facing many difficulties that have arisen during the course of her life.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making snacks

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
This is Milagros, She previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in a higher profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Milagros hopes to be able to expand soon and dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and other products for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Saren

texts.en:
Saren is 31 years old, and his wife, Navin (pictured), is 29 years old. They live in a village about 28 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have two young sons. 

Saren is a lathe operator, while his wife sells grocery items. He is applying for his first Kiva loan in the amount of $1,300 to purchase two cows to raise. He will get extra income from selling the cows for beef or selling a calf when the cow gives birth to a baby.

loans.use: to buy two cows to raise.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more charcoal for her business

loans.name: Mbinty

texts.en: This is 48-year-old Mabinty. She is married and has 3 children aged 18, 15 and 12 years. In 2010, Mabinty established her plastic bowls, beans, bennie, wallah rice and corn flour business. Working 13 hours every day, 7 days a week, she earns about 500,000 SLL every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of 3,000,000 SLL in order to purchase more of her plastic bowls, beans, bennie and other items for resale. She will spend the remaining money on transport. In the future, Mabinty plans to educate her children to university level. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more plastic bowls for resale.

loans.name: Wangnignigbe 8 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe WANGNIGNIGBE 8 est formé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. La représentante  de ce groupe, nommée Zénab, est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. Zénab est âgée de 28 ans et n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Zénab est mariée à un certain Aziz. Le couple a deux enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Zénab vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la maison. Pour  faire face à ses différentes charges, Zénab vend des vêtements d’enfants, des pâtes dentifrices et des jus de fruits de façon secondaire à son domicile et dans un marché du Bénin depuis près de six ans. Zénab s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le souci de renforcer davantage son activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, Zénab désire augmenter le stock de ses produits. Pour ce faire, Zénab sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe WANGNIGNIGBE 8, un crédit auprès de ALIDé
texts.en: The Wangnignigbe 8 group is made up of three people who live in the same neighborhood. The representative of the group, whose name is Zénab, is the one with her hand raised in the photo. Zénab is 28 years old and did not go to school. She is married to man called Aziz. The couple has two children to support, both of whom are at school. Zénab lives with her children and husband. The couple covers the various household expenses between them. In order to do this, Zénab has been selling children's clothing, toothpaste, and fruit juices as a secondary activity, from her home and in a Benin market for almost six years. She buys her products in a Benin market. With a view to boosting her business and responding better to customer demand, Zénab would like to increase her stock. It is for this reason that she, together with the other members of the Wangnignigbe 8 group, is requesting a loan from Alidé.

loans.use: to buy toothpaste and children's clothing.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Mabinty

texts.en: This is 32-year old Mabinty. She is divorced and has 2 children aged 11 and 6. In 2008, Mabinty established her drinks business. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about 1,000,000 SLL every month. She would like a loan in the amount of 6,000,000 SLL. Mabinty requires this loan in order to buy 50 crates of Star beer, 20 crates of stout, 50 cartons of Cody's stout, and 30 cartons of Cody's beer for resale. In the future, Mabinty plans to become an international business woman, build a house of her own and educate her children to university level. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Oyunbayar

texts.en: Mrs.Oyunbayar is a 52-year-old widow who lives with her only daughter in a one-room apartment in Darkhan, the second-largest city in Mongolia. She has worked as a teacher in a local health sciences university for 30 years. Since 2010, she has been managing a small pharmacy near to her home in order to have two sources of income while working. Starting this year her pharmacy is becoming familiar among the neighbors, and her business is going well. Her 26-year-old daughter handles the pharmacy. Before the winter, she is planning to replace the old wooden windows of her apartment and pharmacy with double-glazed ones that conserve heat better. By doing this she can cut heating costs and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to replace the old wooden windows of her apartment and pharmacy with double-glazed ones that conserve heat.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more dried fish to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more copra to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy grocery items for her son's grocery store.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
This is Evangeline. She previously accessed a 30,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) loan that she used buy more products for her food stall such as meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and for her family's personal, household and business expenditures. 

Evangeline would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan so that she can purchase more raw ingredients and supplies for her stall. Her profits will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Evangeline dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education by the grace of God. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients and products needed for her food stall.

loans.name: Luis Alberto

texts.es: Luis Alberto de 40 anos de edad. Soltero con un hijo de tres anos. Él es originario del sauce lugar que esta ubicado en la zona norte del país. Él tiene por negocio la elaboración y venta de labrillos  desde hace 10 anos que se dedica a dicha actividad. Los problemas que enfrenta en el negocio era la época de invierno porque la producción es baja, pero con la llegada del verano la producción se incrementa y las ventas. Luis Alberto ya ha tenido crédito con fundación y ha demostrado su responsabilidad de pago en los créditos anteriores. Con el financiamiento comprara materia prima para la producción de ladrillos como: barro, arena, tierra.  Luis Alberto agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva le brindan a  los pequeños comerciante de escasos recursos para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
Luis Alberto is 40, is single and has a three-year-old child.  He is from El Sauce, a town situated in the North of the country.  He has run his business making and selling bricks for ten years.

The business problems he faces occur during the winter months because production is low, but, when summer arrives, production increases, as do his sales.   

Luis Alberto has already received loans fom the foundation and has proved himself responsible in paying back the previous loans.  He will use the funding to buy raw materials for making bricks, such as: clay, sand and soil.  Luis Alberto is grateful for the help provided by Kiva investors, which helps small traders, with limited resources, to have a decent working environment.

loans.use: to invest in working capital and buy raw materials, such as clay, sand and soil, for making bricks.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
This is Arlene, 40, a resident of Taguig City, Philippines. She is married to Randy, her business partner and father to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Arlene operates a tailoring business. She mainly offers curtains, bed sheets, blankets, and other home products. Items subject to seasonal demand, like  uniforms and such, are available all year round. She also does repairs and alterations. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue her business operations, she is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other items needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Arlene hopes her business grows and dreams to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy fabric, thread and other items needed in her business.

loans.name: Jesukpego Group

texts.fr: JESUKPEGO est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres vivent ensemble dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, Rébéca (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 42 ans. Rébéca est mariée à un certain Romain. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés, dont trois à leur charge. Rébéca vit ensemble avec sa famille. Rébéca a très peu fréquenté l’école. Pour subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants, Rébéca mène comme activité la vente de chaussures dans un marché du Bénin. C’est aussi dans un marché du Bénin que Rébéca s’approvisionne. Rébéca exerce cette activité depuis une vingtaine d’année. C’est la cinquième fois que Rébéca et son groupe JESUKPEGO sollicitent l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue de renforcer leur activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de leur clientèle.
texts.en:
The JESUKPEGO group is composed of three people who live in the same neighborhood. The representative of the group is Rébéca, age 42, seen with her hand raised in the photo. 

Rébéca is married to a man named Romain, and they have four children who have all attended school. Three of them are still under their care. Rébéca lives with herfamily. She received minimal schooling. 

To help support her children, she sells shoes at a market in Benin. She buys her merchandise at another market, also in Benin. She has been in this line of work for about 20 years.  

The group is seeking financial assistance from Alidé for the fifth time to strengthen their activities and better meet customer demand.

loans.use: to buy shoes for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy used sweaters for her thread-making business.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
This is Marilyn. She previously accessed a 13,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and for their personal, household and business expenditures. 

Marilyn would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in increased profits. Her profits from the business will help to sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Marilyn hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams of being able to provide her family with a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up weekly with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work; at these meetings, she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group comprises 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and other products to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy a sewing machine for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.en:
This is Eufemia. She previously accessed a 12,000 PHP loan, which she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed for her grocery store business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in paying for their personal, household and business expenditures. 

Eufemia would like to apply for another 14,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in increased profits. She also has a food stall business. Her profits from the business will help to sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Eufemia hopes her business will grow in the coming years and dreams of being able to give her children a good future and a high-quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group comprises 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed for her store.

loans.name: Stephanie

texts.en:
Stephanie is a 22-year-old woman from Talibon, Bohol. She has operated a sari-sari (convenience) store business in her home for more than a year now. She sells various goods to the people in her community.

Stephanie is asking for a loan to buy additional items to sell such as biscuits, bread, sodas, dry goods and other products. Stephanie is hopeful that this loan will help her improve her business.

In the future, Stephanie dreams of making her business a success and saving money for the future schooling of her 4-year-old daughter.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell such as biscuits, bread, sodas, dry goods and other products.

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie, a 41-year-old resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines, is married to Alfredo, a vendor, and a mother to her children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Josie operates a school/office supplies business where one can buy school supplies including pens, bond paper, greeting cards, etc. without going to a bookstore. Her store is located adjacent to her house, and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 20,000 loan to buy school supplies to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her enterprise.

Josie dreams of giving her children a good quality education, and hopes to have a good life through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for school supplies to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Alma Ligia

texts.es:
La Señora Alma Ligia, posee un negocio de venta de ropa de todo estilo, desde hace dos años, inicia a ofertar su mercadería desde 7:00 am finalizando a  la 5:00 pm de lunes a domingo en este mismo horario, realiza este labor para ayudar a su esposo en los  gastos del hogar es madre de cuatro hijos de los cuales solo dos están a su cargo.

Doña Alma Ligia  está solicitando un crédito el que utilizará  para  comprar  blusas, pañueletas, toallas y ropa interior.
  
Alma Ligia  solicita a  Ceprodel apoyo con un crédito para incrementar su inventario con producto de  mejor calidad y  satisfacer a su  clientela ya que se aproxima la navidad. 

Alma Ligia ha logrado el crecimiento de su negocio con los ingresos obtenido producto de los créditos brindado por Ceprodel.
texts.en:
Alma Ligia has a business of selling clothing of all styles.  She has been working in this business for two years.  She begins to offer her merchandise at 7am and finishes at 5pm, working Monday through Sunday on this same schedule.  

She does this work in order to help her husband with home expenses.  She is the mother of four children, two of which are still in her care.  

Alma Ligia is requesting a loan that she will use to buy blouses, head scarves, towels, and undergarments.  Alma Ligia aska Ceprodel for help with the loan in order to increase her inventory with greater-quality products, and to satisfy her clientele as Christmas approaches.

Alma Ligia has achieved growth in her business with the profits obtained through her loans offered by Ceprodel.

loans.use: to buy blouses, head scarves, towels, and undergarments.

loans.name: Adora

texts.en:
This is Adora, she previously accessed an 10,000 PHP loan that she used to buy RTW [Ready-To-Wear] products and merchandise items to expand her product inventory. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for a 20,000 PHP loan too buy additional stock of merchandise for her business. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Adora hopes to be able to expand her business in the coming years.

She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stock of merchandise needed in her business.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has two children, neither of whom are attending school. She is not looking after any additional family members. She lives in a rented house with access to neither electricity nor piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent.

For the past year, she has been making and selling snacks at retail in a shop she rents. She works seven days a week. She has no other source of income.

She has requested a loan of UGX 100,000 from MCDT-SACCO to enable her buy ingredients like wheat flour and cooking oil and charcoal for fire. Her challenges include seasonality. Her dream is to become a wholesaler of snacks. She joined MCDT because of the low interest charged on loans.

loans.use: To buy more wheat flour, cooking oil and charcoal.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, firewood, and cinnamon.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
This is Arlene, she previously accessed an 50,000 PHP loan that she used to buy additional supplies of RTW (Ready-To-Wear clothing), chlorine and thermal paper products needed for her business. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan to buy additional supplies of materials like paint, screens, and shirts. She will also use the money to buy RTW, chlorine and thermal paper products needed for her business. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Arlene dreams of being able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for paint, screens, and shirts as well as clothing and other items for her business.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
This is Maria, 61, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Herminio, a plumber, and is mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages her household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Maria operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families eat home-cooked meals only during evenings when all of the family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not just a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands cost less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings, and frozen food products. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Maria hopes that her business will expand soon and dreams to have a good life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina is a 50-year-old married woman from Talibon, Bohol. She is a farmer and she grows rice and other crops in her farm lot. Her husband also works as a farmer.

Rosalina works hard to support her husband in meeting the needs of the family, especially for the schooling of their children.
Rosalina is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer for the rice and to pay for the educational expenses of her children. This loan would be a great help for her farm and for the school needs of her children.

In the future, Rosalina hopes to have a sustainable business and see her children as successful professionals some day.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for the rice and to pay for the educational expenses of her children.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George has a cereals business in Naivasha town where he sells maize.  He also has a maize mill business, which enables him to sell maize flour.

This is his second loan term, and he plans to use this loan to buy more maize stock to sell. He will also have enough stock of maize flour to sell to his customers. 

He will use the generated income to pay school fees for his children.

He hopes to invest more in his business by supplying maize, and maize flour, to schools and hotels.

loans.use: To buy more stock of maize.

loans.name: Racheal

texts.en:
Rachael lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with three children, one of whom attends school. She is not looking after any other family members.
She has been selling raw food in the market at retail for the last three years, working seven days a week. She does not have any other source of income. 

She has requested for a loan of 100,000 UGX from MCDT- SACCO to enable her buy more sweet potatoes, Irish potatoes, cassava, pumpkins, and yams to sell. Her challenges include seasonality and transportation. Her dream is to become a wholesaler. She joined MCDT to become rich. She stays with her husband in a rented house with access to electricity and no piped water. Her major monthly expense is rent.

loans.use: to buy more sweet potatoes, Irish potatoes, cassava, pumpkins, and yams to sell.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
This is Delia, She previously accessed a 13,000 PHP loan that she used buy more meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan to purchase raw ingredients and supplies needed in her business. She also has a variety store. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Delia hopes to be able to expand the business soon and dreams of having a beautiful life with her family. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw ingredients and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Fedelina

texts.en:
This is Fedelina, 49, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Pedro, a carpenter, and is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages her household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Fedelina operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Fedelina hopes to expand her business and dreams to have a good life by the grace of God. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with one child who does not attend school. She is not looking after any additional family members.

She has been running a retail boutique away from home for one year, and works six days a week. She does not have another source of income.

She has requested a loan of UShs 100,000 from MCDT- SACCO to enable her to purchase more blouses, shirts, handbags, and skirts to resell. Her challenges include seasonality and defaulters. Her dream is to own a big shop with all kinds of clothing. 

She joined MCDT to raise more capital for her business. 

Annet lives in a rented house with her husband, with access to electricity but no piped water.  Her major monthly expense is rent.

loans.use: To buy more blouses, shirts, handbags and skirts to resell.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan, 38, lives in a common-law union with his wife; he has 3 children. He lives with his wife in a community in Mwambalazi, Coast Province. Hassan works in agriculture, growing vegetables and basic grains.

In order to generate additional income, 3 years ago he started a coconut-selling business. He sells at the market. Hassan’s wife helps him take care of the farm as a way of helping to contribute towards the family economy.

In order to better stock his business, he’s requested a 30,000 KES loan to buy more coconuts to sell. 

He hopes his children will attend a good school. and that he can move his family ahead as the business grows.

loans.use: to buy more coconuts to sell at the market.

loans.name: Tagi

texts.en:
Tagi is 32 years old, married, and has two children.  She has a small plantation where she grows taro, bananas, yams, etc, which she has been doing for two years. 

Tagi is requesting a loan, which she will use to buy new equipment and supplies for her farm. She has been a member of SPBD since 2010. With her profits, Tagi hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase a wheel barrow, bush knife, shovels, fertilizers, and gloves.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a farmer in Ndunyu Njeru town where he plants maize, beans and potatoes. He also keeps dairy cattle and sells milk to various shop retailers. 

He is 27 years old, married to Monica and they have six children.

This is his first loan term and he plans to use the amount to buy a dairy cow. This will enable him to have enough milk to sell. He will use the profits generated from the sale of milk to buy fertilizer and seedlings to plant in his farm.

Peter hopes to invest more in his farming and produce more income and therefore be able to provide for the needs of his family.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Laepa

texts.en:
Laepa is a 57-year-old married woman with 4 children. 

She has a small plantation and grows banana and taro crops to earn a living. She has been doing this for 3 years. Laepa has requested a loan to improve her business by buying new equipment for her business. 

She has been a member of SPBD since 2010. With her profits, Laepa hopes to earn more from her business to provide her family's daily needs.

loans.use: to buy a bush knife, wheelbarrow, fertilizers, and chemicals.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with four children, all of whom attend school. She is not looking after any other family members.

She has been selling fish in the market at retail for the last four years, working seven days a week. She does not have any other sources of income. 

She has requested a loan of 100,000 UGX from MCDT- SACCO to enable her buy more fish to sell. Her challenges include seasonality and transportation. Her dream is to expand her business. She joined MCDT because of the low interest charged on loans. She stays with her husband in a rented house with access to electricity and no piped water. Her major monthly expenses are rent and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Masudi

texts.en:
Masudi is a resident of the town of Mwambalazi. He has one son who is currently in high school. He has had a business in the town center selling motorcycle and vehicle parts for more than 8 years. He has a small garage where he operates from. Masudi says he comes from a hardworking family that is willing to make sacrifices to improve their lives. He is making every effort to be successful.

He has requested this loan to buy motorcycle and vehicle parts so he can continue offering his customers good service and expand his customer base.

loans.use: to buy motorcycle and vehicle parts

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en:
This is Narcisa, 55, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines and a mother to her children. She manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Narcisa maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customers order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalog, and these are the profits that dealers count on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 2,000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 35,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Narcisa hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to have a good life for her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy clothing, footwear, cosmetics and other products for her business.

loans.name: Allan

texts.en:
Allan is a 29-year-old married man and father of four young children ages 1 month, one, six, and nine. For the past six years, he has been engaged in a motorcycle transport business and he transports passengers from one place to another especially in areas that are not accessible to four-wheeled vehicles.

Allan is requesting a loan to buy spare motorcycle parts such as nuts and bolts and to pay for motorcycle maintenance and repair. In the future, he dreams of improving his way of living and exploring other ventures to augment his income.

loans.use: to buy spare motorcycle parts such as nuts and bolts and to pay for motorcycle maintenance and repair

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed, 27, is an enterprising man who sells fuel in his home. He is well known in the area. He has a lot of regular customers, especially motorcyclists.

Mohamed is single and lives with his parents in the market center of Mwambalazi. He started with this line of work four years ago and this has helped him to make a living.

He is now requesting a loan from Yehu, so that he can buy a larger quantity of fuel (petroleum). He will then be able to sell more. There are also times when some of his clients want to buy extra stock to set aside for times of scarcity, so he has to make the most out of this situation.

loans.use: to buy more fuel to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is married and has three children, one of whom attends school.  She lives in Kampala, Uganda. She also cares for her mother. Grace has been selling cooked maize door to door in the market at retail for the last four years. She works seven days a week and does not have any other source of income. 

Grace is requesting a loan from MCDT SACCO for 100,000 UGX, which she will use buy more maize for sale and charcoal for cooking the maize. Her challenges include seasonality and transportation. Her dream is to become a wholesaler of raw maize. 

Grace joined MCDT because of the low interest charged on loans. She lives in a rented house with access to electricity but no piped water.  Her major monthly expense is rent.

loans.use: to purchase maize to sell.

loans.name: Dioscora

texts.en:
Dioscora is a merchant from Talibon, Bohol. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store selling various goods to the people in her community.

Dioscora works hard to earn a living so that she can support her family's needs. Dioscora is asking for a loan to buy additional merchandise to sell in her store, such as soda, snack foods, soap and toiletries. Through this, she will be able to attract more buyers to her store, thus augmenting her income.

Dioscora dreams of making her business a success.

loans.use: to buy sodas, snack foods, soap, toiletries, and other items to sell in her store.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James, a barber shop owner in Naivasha town, is 29 years old and married to Lucy, who runs a grocery business.They have a four-year-old child who is in pre-school. He has been in the business for four years and it has been profitable.

This will be his first loan; he plans to use it to buy shaving equipment for his business. This equipment includes shaving machines, pairs of scissors, razor blades, towels and hair shampoo. He anticipates making more income, with which he plans to open another barber shop.

In the future, James hopes to expand his barber shop business so that he can employ more staff. He also hopes to make more income and be able to provide for the needs of his family.

loans.use: to buy shaving equipment.

loans.name: Sunanik

texts.en:
Sunanik is 48 years old and lives in Pejarakan, North Bali.  She is married and has two children.   Her husband works in transportation services.   She has a small kiosk in front of her house which sells daily needs for  families, such as rice, oil, soap, kitchen needs, etc. She has been in this business for two years.  

Sunanik is seeking a loan of 2M IDR from MUK to expand her business. With the loan, she will purchase more snacks to stock in her kiosk and also pay the rent of her house.  With her earnings, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her first child who is already in university now.

loans.use: To purchase more snacks to stock in her kiosk

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma  lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with two children, one of whom attends school. She is not looking after any other family member.

She has been selling human drugs at retail in a drug store for the last year and working seven days a week.  She does not have any other source of income. 

She has requested a loan of UShs 100,000 from MCDT- SACCO to enable her to buy different types of human drugs for sale. Her challenges include seasonality. Her dream is to be able to stock all drugs. She joined MCDT because of the low interest charged on loans. She lives with her husband in a rented house without access to electricity or piped water.  Her major monthly expense is rent.

loans.use: To buy more drugs (human ) like boxes of medicines and malaria syringes

loans.name: Merilyn

texts.en:
Merilyn is 46 years old and is a married woman with a 6-year-old child from Talibon, Bohol. 

Merilyn has run a sari-sari (variety) store business for several years now. She is asking for a loan to buy additional stocks to sell such as snacks, canned goods, toiletries, soap and others. Through this loan, Merilyn hopes to enhance her sales and profits.

Merilyn hopes to make her business a success in the future and make it sustainable.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks to sell such as snacks, canned goods, toiletries, soap and others.

loans.name: Idd

texts.en:
Idd is single gentleman who is in his early 30's. He is a hardworking and goal-oriented person.

Idd has been involved in a motorcycle service for two years. In addition, he also sells fuel from their home where he has a small store. He is requesting a loan in the sum of Ksh 50,000 to repair the motorcycle. He will also buy gallons of fuel to sell. He relies on your help and support.

loans.use: to buy gallons of fuel and repair his motorcycle

loans.name: Airesty

texts.en:
